translated: Bodhisattva's Necklace Sutra, Scroll 6, also known as Present Retribution
Translated by the Yao Qin Dynasty monk Zhu Fonian from Liangzhou
Chapter 18: The Immeasurable Eons (6)
The Buddha said:

Good men and good women who uphold and practice the three meditations will attain the perfection of all good merits and virtues, and will travel to various buddha-lands to make offerings and serve the buddhas, the world-honored ones.
At that time, the World-Honored One, in the midst of the great assembly, spoke this verse:
The buddhas of the past, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges, all relied on the three meditation methods,
The Dharma of signlessness and non-aspiration, which accords with the practice of the noble precepts.
The fundamental Dharma of the three meditations leads one to attain nirvana,
Even if one recites it immeasurably, one is still unable to exhaust its Dharma.
If there were a single person who lived for immeasurable eons,
Within that time, wishing to proclaim it, one would not exhaust the basis of the three meditations.
Observing one's past consciousness, it cannot be proclaimed by the mind.
The future consciousness is also like this, consciousness is neither existent nor non-existent,
Formless and invisible, yet it plants the disease of birth and death,
Contemplating the dharmas of the nine grounds, one then attains enlightenment.
The pure Dharma of pure conduct, protecting the teachings of the TathÄgata,
Desiring to distinguish each and every one, not yet fully understanding the TathÄgata's body.
The unequaled Honored One of the three times, destroying the nets of desires and existences,
Pulling out the bonds and attachments, forever extinguished without remainder.
Observing the changes of existences in the world, birth after birth, never remaining constant,
How much more so for desiring to know the basis of consciousness, the present body of six abodes.
I originally did not create existence, tainted existence then gives rise to defilement,
All due to the dharmas of the three concentrations, then sitting under the bodhi tree.
If there is a clansman, the mind of giving wishing to measure and calculate,
Distinguishing the TathÄgata's body, coming is all like a hair.
The past Dharma realms, each inconceivable,
By means of these three dhyÄnas, one can attain the name and title.
If one wishes to calculate the basis of consciousness, distinguishing non-existent dharmas,
The numberless transformations one goes to, then one should accord with the practice of the three dhyÄnas.
If my birth is already at ease, I can also bring peace to the multitude of people,
However, people have many thoughts, I lead and guide them to know.
I from the originally equal concentration, practice contemplation and awareness of the three dhyÄnas,
Not the thought of consciousness on the ground of existence, transcending past practices.
Birth originally from self and others, flowing and turning to the five destinies,
Able to exhaust the defilements of one lifetime, then called in accord with the three dhyÄnas.
Ultimately there are three dharmas, carefully examining the essential defilements of the basis,
Two are the wisdom of the present, the contemplation of the path is called the three.
Able to exhaust the meaning and purport, the immeasurable practices of the three concentrations,
This is also inconceivable, thoroughly exhausting the practices of the three dharmas.
Moreover, knowing the basis of affection and love, gradually turning into concentration,
Having received from the teacher oneself, later one attains the enlightenment of the Way.
Sometimes manifesting in the three thousand worlds, like observing a pearl in the palm of one's hand,
Each and every one enters pure observation, washing away all afflictions and troubles.
If a person tries to measure emptiness, wanting to measure it with a bushel or a peck,
Although one may set one's mind on this, how could there be such a principle?
The mind's thoughts have no boundaries, birth after birth without ceasing,
Like water flowing into the ocean, one does not see any increase or decrease.
How much more so does a person want to measure the fundamental basis of the mind,
Wanting to seek the thoughts of the mind, how could there be such a principle?
The reason why the sage descends and manifests in the world,
To know its measure in bushels and liters.ğŸ”½Discerning the arising of thoughts, moment by moment,
Before, after, and in between,
Each and every one can be known, cutting off the root of birth and death.
The human mind is not of one kind, creating various kinds of actions,
Falling back into the fundamental state, eventually sinking into the abyss.ğŸ”½The past Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges,
All the teachings are the same,ğŸ”½All due to the practice of the three samadhis,
Attaining the unsurpassed Way.ğŸ”½The Tathagatas of the future,
Will also uphold this practice,
Peacefully abiding all sentient beings, together attaining the realization of the Way.
As I now become a Buddha, ruling over these worlds,ğŸ”½It is also due to the wisdom of the three times,
Attaining the unsurpassed Way.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this verse, he then told the good men and good women:

In the past, countless eons ago, there was a Buddha who appeared, named the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One with Perfect Wisdom and Action, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the Secular World, the Unexcelled Person, the Trainer and Teacher of Heavenly Beings and People, the Buddha, the World-Honored One. He also attained Buddhahood at this very place.
At that time, there was a king named JÄ«vanta who ruled this land. The people flourished, the five grains were abundant, and he possessed the seven treasures.
The so-called seven treasures are:

the treasure of the pearl, the treasure of the wheel, the treasure of the jade maiden, the treasure of the horse, the treasure of the elephant, the treasure of the minister of the treasury, and the treasure of the minister of war.
He also had a thousand sons, all skilled in martial arts and proficient in the six arts.

At that time, King Jipul, having grown old and feeble, wished to relinquish his royal status to cultivate pure conduct under that Tathagata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One. He passed on the royal status to his eldest prince and went to see the Buddha, seeking to cultivate pure conduct. He pursued that Buddha's twelve years of cultivation of these three dhyanas, yet still did not understand the meaning of a single phrase.

Furthermore, since the passing of that Buddha, there were twenty great kalpas without a Buddha. Later, a Buddha appeared, and he again went to that Buddha to cultivate pure conduct. In this way, he passed through twelve koá¹­Ä«s of nayutas of Buddhas, each of whom he served and cultivated pure conduct under.

Furthermore, since then he has made offerings to countless Buddhas for a long time, and only later encountered the Tathagata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One Guangming, under whom he received the wisdom of the three dhyanas, which he has only now attained.
The Buddha told those who had gathered:
Was the king Jipul of that time someone else?
Do not think like this.
Why is it so?
At that time, King Jipul is now me, Shakyamuni Buddha, the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Since then, I have now attained this fundamental practice of the three dhyanas, and have become a Buddha sitting in the place of enlightenment.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
I remember accumulating merits and virtues, encountering countless Buddhas,
Encountering various afflictions and troubles, unable to save myself.
In the meantime, I made offerings to Buddhas as numerous as the sands of the Ganges,
Giving away my wife, children, country, and wealth, yet not attaining these three dharmas.
Later, I encountered the Venerable Light, and only then attained this venerable wisdom,
In the meantime, cultivating pure practices, only then awakening to the Dharma of the three dhyanas.
Tranquil and free from worries and fears, unborn and unstained,
Adorned with various marks, thus called the Honored One among humans.
By my impartial wisdom, I do not give rise to various attachments,
Transforming the celestial and human worlds, I am the honored one in charge of the three realms.
At that time, after the World-Honored One spoke this verse, the hundreds of thousands of millions of beings in the assembly all gave rise to the intention for unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
Moreover, the various celestial beings and humans, according to their thoughts, each accomplished their goals.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva named Pure who addressed the Buddha, saying:
A wheel-turning sage king who rules over the four continents is able to fully possess the seven treasures, and only then is he called a wheel-turning sage king.
The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One has the seven factors of enlightenment, and only then is he called the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One.
I now ask the TathÄgata:
Do the seven factors have form?
Or are they formless?
The Buddha said:
Stop, stop!
Son of a great clan!
I now understand your eloquence.
As the son of a great clan asks, the seven dharmas of the TathÄgata are formless.
Why is it so?
This Dharma is extremely profound and inexhaustible, but it appears to have an end for the sake of sentient beings, yet this sevenfold Dharma is inexhaustible.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Pure said to the Buddha:
Do the seven treasures of the wheel-turning king have form?
Or are they formless?
The Buddha said:
They both have form and have sentience, and they both have form and are insentient.
What does it mean to have form and have sentience?
The precious maiden, the precious elephant, the precious horse, the precious minister of the treasury, and the precious minister of the army - these have form and have sentience.
What does it mean to have form and be insentient?
The precious wheel and the precious pearl - these have form and are insentient.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Pure said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

It is like when a wheel-turning sage king is sitting in heaven, whatever he thinks of, it immediately arrives. At that time, does it have form and consciousness, and does it arrive because the king thinks of it?
Or does it arrive without consciousness?
The Buddha said:
Although it has consciousness and arrives because the king thinks of it, it does not know the king's intention to arrive.
Pure Bodhisattva said to the Buddha:
Although it has consciousness, how is it different from the wheel treasure and the pearl treasure?
The Buddha said:
What do you think, son of a great clan?
The wheel treasure and the pearl treasure also arrive due to thought, but do these two have sound and verbal teachings?
Pure Bodhisattva said:
They have no verbal teachings.
The Buddha said:
So it is, son of a great clan!
Although it has consciousness and arrives due to thought, it does not take verbal teachings.
Pure Bodhisattva again said to the Buddha:
What is it, World-Honored One!
If a wheel-turning sage king thinks of something, it immediately arrives. Can he make the wheel treasure and the pearl treasure have speech and instruction?
The Buddha said:
He can.
Why is it so?
Because of the wheel-turning king's majestic power, they will have speech and instruction.
The pure bodhisattva said:
The wheel-turning sage king is neither enlightened nor inspired. How can he make insentient things have speech and instruction?
The Buddha said:
The wheel-turning sage king attains worldly spiritual powers and can make worldly objects accord with his thoughts, but he is still unable to make sentient beings reach insentient things.
The pure bodhisattva said again:
How can he make sentient beings reach insentient things?
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
I will now explain to you one by one how to make sentient beings reach insentient things and insentient things reach sentient beings.
Think about it carefully, and I will now explain it to you.
It is like a wheel-turning sage king observing those sentient beings with form and love, unable to let go, wishing to make them eternally exist without any change.
He thinks to himself, having received the sage king's position, he only sees their blessings without seeing their destruction. This is called wanting to make formless things have form.
It is like a good son or good woman who has already attained the path, always thinking to themselves:
I now abandon the old and no longer love or enjoy it, wishing to destroy this form and not be tainted by consciousness.
This is called having form but extinguishing form.
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!

It is like the four dharma realms, where one dharma realm increases and the other realms are diminished, and all the realms increase and one realm is diminished. This is due to sentient beings increasing, not due to insentient beings increasing.
The pure bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
As the World-Honored One has said, I will now explain how sentient beings reach insentience and insentient beings reach sentience;
Now the TathÄgata only speaks of sentient beings attaining non-sentience, but never hears the TathÄgata speak of non-sentient beings attaining sentience.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
Your present question is all due to the Buddha's majestic spiritual power.
I will now counter-question you, and you should answer me one by one.
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!

If there are good sons and good women who are initially on the stage of learning and have accomplished the seven impure contemplations of the stage of learning, are there then the minds of ordinary beings in the past, future, and present?
He replied:
No, there are not.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is.
Son of a great clan!
This is called non-sentient beings attaining sentience.
The Buddha further asked the Pure Bodhisattva:
What do you think?
Son of a great clan!
Now that there is the cultivation of the nine pure paths of one beyond learning, are there then the seven impure contemplations?
He replied:
No, there is not.ğŸ”½
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said again:
Son of a great clan!
When the irreversible bodhisattva attains the observation of emptiness and cultivates the sixteen noble practices, does he then cultivate the nine pure paths of no-more-learning?
He replied:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is.
Son of a great clan!
This is called the absence of mind in sentient beings.
The Buddha asked again:
What do you think, son of a great clan?
Now that the bodhisattva of the eighth stage has attained the physical characteristics of a buddha and obtained the thirty-two noble truths, are there then nine pure paths?
He replied:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is.
Son of a great clan!
This is called the absence of mind in sentient beings.
The Buddha asked the pure bodhisattva again:
What do you think, son of a great clan?
Do the bodhisattvas of the ninth ground still have the thirty-two aspects of the truth of the holy ones?
He replied:
No, they do not.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
It is just as you have said.
Son of a great clan!
This is called having no feelings towards those with feelings.
The Buddha further asked the Pure Bodhisattva:
How is it?
Son of a great clan!
Now, as the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, finally subdues the fourteen kinds of dust and defilements, do the bodhisattvas still have the three concentrations at that time?
He replied:
No, they do not.
World-Honored One!
The Buddha said:
It is just as you have said.
Son of a great clan!
This is called having no feelings towards those with feelings.
The Buddha further told the Pure Bodhisattva:

Now I have explained to you how sentient beings are in insentient things and insentient things are in sentient beings. You can then fully understand the teachings of the TathÄgata, ascend to the stage of the bodhisattvas, and progress to the site of enlightenment, just like the moon is the brightest among the stars, illuminating everything without exception.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess this understanding of sentient beings in insentient things and insentient things in sentient beings can then fully understand the TathÄgata's holy practices, have a golden-colored body with majestic virtues, like a purple-gold mountain, and have mastery over various knowledges.
At that time, Bodhisattva Purity said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Today, the TathÄgata, the Worthy of Offerings, the Perfectly Enlightened One, are sentient beings in insentient things?
Are insentient things in sentient beings?
At that time, the World-Honored One, having heard Bodhisattva Purity's question, emitted a light from his body that illuminated the lands of innumerable buddhas, all turning them golden.
The light was retracted, and he then said to the Bodhisattva Pure:
Excellent, excellent!
Son of a great clan!
You now ask the TathÄgata about this meaning using the Dharma of signlessness.

Because the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One has already transcended the nine grounds, sentient beings in insentient beings attain Buddhahood up to the site of enlightenment, this is called insentient beings in sentient beings.
Why is it so?
It is all because sentient beings have attachment.
At that time, the Bodhisattva Pure again said to the Buddha:
As the World-Honored One has said, it is for the sake of sentient beings that insentient beings have sentient beings. Has the TathÄgata not yet departed from this today?
The Buddha said:
I have already departed, although I dwell I am not tainted.
He further asked:
How is it?
World-Honored One!
Does the TathÄgata distinguish sentient beings, causing insentient beings to have sentient beings, or are there only insentient beings in sentient beings?
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
The TathÄgata has no separate feelings towards sentient beings, nor does he have insentient feelings towards sentient beings;
He only has the ultimate truth, so he has no feelings towards sentient beings.
Pure Bodhisattva asked again:ğŸ”½What is it to have no feelings towards sentient beings?
What is it to have no feelings towards insentient beings?
The Buddha said:
Son of a great clan!
I have no mind of pratyekabuddha or arhat, but I have loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, which is called having no feelings towards sentient beings.
Pure Bodhisattva said:
The TathÄgata has no feelings towards sentient beings today. Are there any who have no feelings towards insentient beings?
The Buddha said:
There are.
Pure Bodhisattva asked:
Who are they?
The Buddha said:
My mind now ceases and rests in the unconditioned, which is called having no feelings towards insentient beings.
Pure Bodhisattva asked:
Is the unconditioned also sentient? Is the insentient also sentient? Are these names and designations?
What is it?
The World-Honored One said that my mind now ceases and relies on the unconditioned?
The Buddha said:
Son of a good family!
It is just as you have said.
All dharmas are all provisional names, and there is also sentience in insentience and insentience in sentience.
The Pure Bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
As the World-Honored One has said, all dharmas are confused, all dharmas are not fixed, and all dharmas are impermanent.
How, within the dharmas of provisional names, does one again speak of insentience in sentience and sentience in insentience?
The Buddha said:
What do you think?
Son of a good family!
I will now ask you about the ultimate truth, and you should answer me one by one.
Do you now have sentience?
Or are you insentient?
He replied:
I have sentience.
The Buddha said:
Where does your sentience stand?
He replied:
It stands in insentience.
The Buddha said:
You now have feelings, how can you establish yourself in the absence of feelings?
He replied:
Abandoning the realm of existence, I therefore establish myself in the absence of feelings.
The Buddha said:
Since there are no feelings, what is established?
He replied:
Establishing the unestablished.
The Buddha said:
What kind of dharma do you now use to establish the unestablished?
He replied:
I now do not see sentient beings, nor do I see insentient beings, therefore I establish the unestablished.
The Buddha said:
Son of a noble family!
You say that all dharmas are provisional names.
How, within provisional named dharmas, do you speak of sentient beings in the absence of feelings, and speak of the absence of feelings in the presence of sentient beings?
If it were so, then dharmas would be chaotic, dharmas would be indeterminate, dharmas would be impermanent;
You now also say that because there are neither sentient beings nor insentient beings, you establish the unestablished.
At that time, the bodhisattva Pure remained silent and did not reply.
The Buddha said:
Son of a good family!
What principle do you contemplate that you remain silent and do not reply?
The bodhisattva Pure said:
I contemplate that in the ultimate truth there is no speech and no expression, so I remain silent.
The Buddha said:
So it is, so it is.
Son of a good family!

All dharmas are all provisional names. Within provisional named dharmas, there is neither truth nor existence. Due to defiled thoughts, sentient beings do not understand and each proclaims this is nirvana, this is birth and death;
With the contemplation of the ultimate truth and purity, there is neither nirvana nor birth and death.
At that time, the World-Honored One then spoke this verse:
All dharma realms, originally non-existent and non-existent,
The non-penetrating contemplation of birth and death, is considered the dharma itself.
Experiencing the three temporal worlds, seeking the bodhisattva path,
How could there be one who reaches the fundamental non-existence?
The Ten Powers compassionately appear in the world, having pity and thinking of all beings equally,
Expounding the Dharma of provisional names, causing them to know the bright ultimate Way.
Liberation has no equal companion, quickly expounding the Dharma sound,
Satisfying the immeasurable multitudes of beings with the sweet dew of the Dharma.
The great Way has no form or appearance, it is neither sentient nor insentient,
But if one only gives rise to a defiled mind, one will not attain the basis of the three concentrations.
If one wishes to cultivate the basis, the pure seven without outflows,
Proclaiming the nine pure grounds, this is called the gateway to entering the Way.
At first wishing to enter the Way-place, attached to the fourteen minds,
Only after attaining Buddhahood will it be extinguished, then accomplishing the fruit of the Way.
The sixteen noble truths, the Dharma seals of all bodhisattvas,
The sweet dew wisdom of receiving the prediction, therefore called the TathÄgata.
The thirty-two Dharma foundations, the spiritual powers and wisdom of the bodhisattvas,
Eliminate the afflictions of the three times, gradually reaching nirvana.
Those who wish to seek the Buddha's path, adorn various buddha-lands,
Their voice pervades the worlds of the ten directions, they attain this by cultivating meditation.
The practice of the three dhyanas without outflows, the profound treasury of the buddhas,
They make vows for the sake of sentient beings and expound the Dharma of no death.
Actions are exhausted without creating actions, and fruits also have no karmic retribution,
The path follows impartial wisdom, the mind is single without any wrong thoughts.
The four kinds of faith in the treasure of the Tathagata, the six kinds are the dust of the world,
The garland of the seven kinds of purity, the eight kinds of equipment are accomplished.
The five supernatural powers of the mundane world, like a bird passing through the sky,
Their life is bound to the great earth, they cannot escape the difficulties of birth and death.
The path of the Mahayana with the six supernatural powers, playing in the abyss of empty space,
Ultimately not regressing, this peace is not lacking.
Insightful observation reaches purity, illuminating all within darkness,
Unattached and unstained, thus called the Heavenly Honored One.
The Way arises not from self-arising, but from conditions there is the Way.
Dharmas do not know themselves, empty and still, what is the Way?
People originally dwell in birth and death, wandering without self-awareness,
Vigorously advancing without indolence, gradually conforming to the sage's precepts.
The mind-pearl is originally bright, not relying on external light.
The sun and moon have five veils, how can they illuminate anything?
The Buddha's original practice is pure, the wisdom of the mind is free from flaws and dust,
Self-liberated and liberating others, unobstructed wherever he goes.
Able to sever all hopes and aspirations, eliminating all bonds and attachments,
Illuminating with the light of all dharmas, the ignorant darkness does not know.
The nature of nirvana is pure, and one does not see coming or going,
Deep and subtle, invisible, tranquil and unchanging.
Entering meditation with a single focused mind, one moves the ten directions,
With the strong power of spiritual feet and the eight equalities, not lacking.
Therefore, giving rise to great vows, raining tears and pitying sentient beings,
All thinking to replace them in suffering, this is truly extraordinary.
People do not consider impermanence, greedily attached to the glory of the three realms,
Like wind blowing fallen leaves, transmigrating and following their destination.
Space has no boundaries, and the practice of the Way is also boundless,
Emptiness is repaid with sound, empty and tranquil, without a fundamental basis.
People originally emerge from their mother's womb, following their actions and staining the five destinies,
Good and evil pursue the human form, like a shadow following the body.
If one can extinguish the five aggregates, the spirit and consciousness return to emptiness,
No longer born, aging, or dying, this is true happiness.
If one knows the profound and unfathomable treasury of the buddhas,
One transcends the realms and surpasses the three times, looking back at the shore of birth and death.
Originally, I was foolish and confused, entering this blazing cauldron,
Now I have escaped this disaster and play in the pure pool.
Although I have now escaped suffering, I have left it myself but not others.
Self-benefit is not a great vow, why would I necessarily attain nirvana?
Returning again to manifest birth, skillfully transforming in the midst of afflictions,
Extensively saving without limit, not wearying of the duration of eons.
Daily liberating like the sands of the Ganges, like oneself without equal,
Not calculating like a hair's breadth, proclaiming one's own merits and virtues,
Not thinking of the nearness of those liberated, the distance for those not yet liberated,
The mind and consciousness are serene and unified, ultimately without obstruction.
Physical appearance is the endowment of the body, with a countenance and beauty unmatched by any,
The faculties are fully mature, up to being greatly joyful.
Having sharp faculties and fully practicing, awakening gradually,
Meeting with the foolish is very difficult.
The Bodhisattva enters concentration, not thinking of existence or non-existence,
Walking alone without fear, virtue surpassing all mountains.
The practitioner has five categories, with intermediate dharmas of advancing and retreating,
Establishing resolve like Mount Sumeru, the mind firm and unmoving.
The great wisdom of the six pÄramitÄs, with spiritual powers coming and going,
The dharma realm without the three thoughts, thus able to turn the wheel of dharma.
Originally accumulating immeasurable goodness, naturally attaining sagehood among the benevolent,
The Way is equal, without the three bases, the mind calculating the purity of the inner and outer.
The nature and practice have various aspects, but the practice of the Dharma is without difference,
There are distinctions in their analysis.
Transgressions lead to eons of affliction, never giving rise to thoughts,
Thus wandering the boundless mind, empty space without obstruction.
The earth is the basis of sincerity, able to endure defilement and purity,
Wisdom embraces the mind, not seeing those who are liberated and those who are not.
The sage's practice is extremely wondrous, able to endure these many sufferings,
Practicing merits for eons, then accomplishing a single principle.
The three concentrations are empty, signless, and wishless, practicing all dharmas,
The various knowledges, ten powers, and wisdom transcend the place of non-arising.
Originally cultivating the wisdom of sound and resonance, the eight sounds are extremely pure and wondrous,
Distinguishing the five aggregates' practices, eliminating thoughts and desires.
Sinking in the basis of birth and death, not seeking the path of liberation,
Not abandoning the three bases and their basis, then leaving through the essential path.
The supernormal knowledge of recollecting past lives, the inconceivable Dharma body,
Destroying existence and forming non-existence, etc., this power cannot be obstructed.
The immeasurable realm of space is neither one nor two or three,
Following the original vows and practices, purifying the myriad wonderful paths.
The defiled dharmas of birth and death are what foolish people crave and enjoy,
The wise contemplate without attachment, forever eliminating the deluded and confused dharmas.
The bodhisattva delights in tranquility and contemplates the immeasurable dharmas,
In the present, there is neither birth nor cessation, neither existence nor non-existence.
The knowledge of recollecting past lives, contemplating the roots of birth and death,
Like a person standing on the edge of a river or ocean, trembling with fear.
Vast vows to reach the other shore, practicing the path of equality,
Sitting, lying down, entering deep concealment, always avoiding defiled conduct.
Earth, water, fire, wind, and space, the spirit and consciousness rely on and abide in,
Desiring to seek a cave for meditation, they do not know where the spirit and consciousness go.
People's faith is also like this. Due to causes and conditions, they gather together,
But when consciousness separates from the four great elements, it becomes empty, and they do not know where each goes.
The ocean of Dharma has no boundaries. It receives and enters internal and external dust,
Yet its inherent nature is originally pure and clean, and one does not know how to distinguish defilement.
The great way originally has no Dharma. Contemplating the purity inside and outside the Dharma,
One does not think of the past, present, and future. Worldly wisdom is unmatched.
Understanding all the sounds of the multitude, the Dharma with measure and without measure,
The Dharma that is destroyed by the number of kalpas, how could there be anything that permanently remains?
One can cut off the difficulties of sentient beings and forever leave the ground of the four demons,
Greed and jealousy originally have no nature. Only then does one accord with pure contemplation.
Originally sitting under the king of trees, the same in the middle of the first night,
With one mind and one intention, the concentrated mind is no longer disturbed.
For seven days, his body did not lean, and he observed the dharmas of the three times,
Destroying one, without again having one, from this he then awakened.
Now that he has attained Buddhahood, he pities those who have not yet been liberated,
And turns the unsurpassed Dharma, in the Deer Park.
